ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The storage of aqueous ammonia at the City of Pasadena Broadway Power Plant is governed by many safety features.  Much of the safety of the processes is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the process.  For example, the Broadway Plant operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  The aqueous ammonia system is checked by operators on a daily basis.

The City of Pasadena Power Plant facility maintains tight control of the aqueous ammonia systems through various process controls and monitors.  In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the facility fail and result in a release of aqueous ammonia, there are three mechanisms at the facility to minimize the impact:  1) ammonia vapor detectors, 2) liquid sensor, and 3) associated alarms.  There are a total of four (4) vapor detectors located in the following locations at the Broadway Plant:  Bermed Storage Area, Feed Pump Skid, Vaporizer Area, and Catalyst Expansion Joint.  All ammonia sensors activate an audible alarm in the Control Room and display an alarm on the computer control system in the Control Room to alert the operator at 5 ppm. The control room is always manned.   

Other automatic protections that are designed to mitigate or prevent a release of aqueous ammonia include: containment berms surrounding the aqueous ammonia tanks are d to hold the entire contents of the tanks, double walled piping from the pumps' discharge to the stacks, and valves that will automatically engage to relieve pressure or vacuum (negat

ive pressure) in the tanks.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP regulation defines accident as the following:
The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:

- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the City of Pasadena Water & Power - Broadway Power Plant's accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (February 24, 2014), there was one documented release of aqueous ammonia at the aqueous ammonia system at the Broadway Power Plant.

On April 12, 2012 at 11:15 AM, a puff of ammonia was released during a maintenance repair of the damaged flow indicator associated with the B-3 ammonia metering pump.  During the removal process of the sight glass, the operator released the pressure too quickly which releases a small amount of residual aqueous ammonia liquid into the operator's face, mouth, and eyes.  The operator was wearing safety glasses and rubber gloves.  The operator was sent to a nearby clinic and was diagnosed with conjunctivitis (pink eye) due to ammonia exposure.  There were no lasting injuries or damage on-site or off-site.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The City of Pasadena Broadway Power Plant facility, located in Pasadena, California, utilizes aqueous ammonia, 29.4% weight anhydrous ammonia, in the Unit B-3 Steam Plant Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to help maintain air quality compliance of the emission stack, specifically, reducing NOx (NO and NO2) emissions.  

Senior management at the facility is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities.  Senior management administers the safety and environmental policies and programs.  These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers' documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

The City of Pasadena Broadway Power Plant facility has independently coordinated emergency response efforts with the local Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia related emergency, it is the policy of the City of Pasadena Broadway Power Plant to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency.  If an ammonia release could potentially impact the local community, a Co

mmunity Notification Plan would be activated. If an ammonia release were to extend into the neighboring community, a Shelter-In-Place plan would go into effect.  


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The City of Pasadena Broadway Power Plant facility is located at 85 E. State Street in Pasadena, California. The facility is located at Glenarm Street and Arroyo Parkway at the northern end of the 110 freeway.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of commercial, industrial, and residential areas.     

In the aqueous ammonia process, the liquid aqueous ammonia is pulled from the tank through the ammonia shut off valve by two pumps.  It then travels through double walled piping, underground, to the first level of the Broadway Power Plant.  There it flows through a strainer manifold and then travels up to the fifth level where it flows through a back pressure regulator control valve, a flow control valve to the vaporizer and then the injection grid.  The catalyst bed provides the surface area for the SCR reactions to occur.
 
The ammonia shut off valve remains open based on several permissive conditions including, but not limited to boiler load, reactor temperature, ammonia storage tank level, and metering pump operation.  The aqueous ammonia is mixed with compressed air prior to entering the vaporizer where it is mixed with hot blower air and then fed to either the economizer superheat-side or the economizer reheat-side of the ammonia injection grid in the combustion exhaust stack.

The NOx in the flue gas reacts with ammonia in the SCR reactor catalyst layers to form harmless elemental nitrogen and water.  The elemental nitrogen and water remain in the flue gas as it passes through the stack to the atmosphere.  The SCR reactor is designed for a NOx reduction efficiency of 89.3% when firing natural gas.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analysis Revalidation conducted on February 24, 2014, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, a completion of several checklists, and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the City of Pasadena Power Plant facility in Pasadena, California. The City of Pasadena Power Plants safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility safety plan/programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in safety plan development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
